column2: What should you do if you break down on a level crossing, even if the lights haven't yet begun to flash?
column3: Leave your vehicle and get yourself and any passengers well clear
column4: Continue down the track and attempt to signal any oncoming trains
column5: Tell others what the issue is
column9: Getting everyone out of the vehicle and away from the crossing should be your first priority following a breakdown on a level crossing. Warn the signal operator via the railway telephone (if one is present), and only attempt to move the vehicle if the alarm signals are not yet on.

column2: You arrive at the scene of an accident and find someone has suffered a burn which needs to be treated. How long should the burn be cooled for?
column9: A burn should be cooled for at least 20 minutes. Cool it with a cool, clean, non-toxic liquid. Water ideally. You should also check the casualty for shock.

column2: You arrive at the scene of an incident. Several people are badly injured. After turning on your hazard lights and ensuring all engines are off, what should you do?
column3: Wave down other motorists for help
column4: Pull any casualties away from the vehicle(s)
column5: Provide sweet drinks for anyone injured
column9: You shouldn't assume someone else has already contacted the emergency services, and should phone them yourself. It's also important to make sure there is no further danger. Check that engines are off and that hazard warning lights are turned on, reducing the risk of fire or further collision.

column2: You are approaching a long tunnel. Which of these should you do?
column4: Lower your sun visor and put your sunglasses on
column6: Tune your radio to the frequency shown on signs
column9: You'll often see signs for local radio channels as you approach a tunnel. These radio stations warn of traffic, incidents, or congestion within the tunnel; some radios have settings allowing them to automatically pick up these signals. Ensure tuning the radio doesn't distract you. Using these radio stations will give advance warning of hazards within the tunnel, preventing issues from escalating. Fire is the greatest risk in a tunnel due to risk of suffocation from smoke.

column2: What should you do if your car catches fire in a tunnel, but is still driveable?
column3: Continue out of the tunnel if possible
column4: Leave the engine running and exit the vehicle
column5: Stop as far to one side of the tunnel as possible
column6: Stop and walk to the nearest emergency telephone
column9: If it's possible to continue on without causing further danger, you should continue to drive out of the tunnel. Smoke gathers in tunnels, presenting risk of suffocation.

column2: There has been a road traffic accident and someone is bleeding from their arm. There is nothing embedded in the wound. How should you help this person?
column3: Dab the wound with a cloth
column4: Raise their arm and apply pressure
column6: Lower their arm and apply pressure
column9: The casualty should be laid down if possible, and the wound should be checked for debris. Use a clean material to apply pressure to the wound without pressing any debris into the wound. If you can, raise the arm above heart level to slow blood loss.

column2: What should you do if your car catches fire in a tunnel, but is NOT driveable?
column3: Close the windows and stay in the vehicle
column4: Turn on your hazard warning lights, leave the vehicle, then call for help
column5: Turn off your lights and leave the vehicle
column6: Leave the engine running and leave the vehicle
column9: While the best option is usually to continue driving, this is sometimes not possible. Pull over at an emergency point (if there is one), switch on our hazard warning lights, and leave the vehicle to call for help. An on-board fire extinguisher may be enough to deal with small fires, but leave large fires to the professionals.

column2: Following an incident, a casualty has a bleeding arm but can move it freely. Why should you ask them to move it into a raised position?
column3: To allow emergency services to recognise them
column4: To reduce blood flow and bleeding
column6: To prevent them from touching other people
column9: Raising the arm above heart level will reduce the flow of blood and lessen blood loss. You should make sure the arm isn't broken before raising it, as this could lead to further injury.

column2: Following an accident, an unconscious injured person has been placed in the recovery position. Their breathing is normal. What else should you do?
column4: Lower their arms to their sides
column6: Press down between their shoulder blades
column9: You should ensure their airway remains clear, monitoring their condition until medical help arrives. Unless there is further danger, do not move the casualty.

column2: You are driving behind a lorry on the motorway. A large box falls from the vehicle onto the road. How should you react?
column3: Continue until the next emergency telephone and report it
column4: Follow the driver and flash your lights to get their attention
column5: Pull onto the hard shoulder and retrieve the box
column6: Stop your car near the box until police arrive
column9: Given the size of their vehicles, it's not uncommon for lorry drivers to miss seeing objects falling from their vehicles. If the driver doesn't stop following this happening, don't attempt to rescue the object. Instead, stop safely on the hard shoulder and report the hazard on an emergency telephone.

column2: An adult isn't breathing at the scene of a crash. To save the casualty, you must administer chest compressions. What is the correct chest compression depth?
column9: A compression depth of 5-6 centimetres is correct. Place both hands in the centre of the casualty's chest and give two chest compressions every second (120 per minute). This maintains circulation in adult casualties who aren't breathing properly.

column2: You have broken down on a motorway and must use the emergency telephone. What will you be asked for?
column9: While on the emergency telephone, the operator will ask for your vehicle details and the reason for the breakdown. Whilst on the phone to the operator, you should face traffic so you can see what's coming.

column2: A motorcyclist has been involved in an accident and is unconscious in the middle of the road. There are no other people or vehicles involved. What should you do first?
column3: Pull the rider out of the road
column6: Reassure the rider that everything will be fine
column9: Warning other traffic should be your first priority, ensuring there is no risk of further collision. Turn on your hazard warning lights to warn other drivers, and ensure all engines are turned off to reduce risk of fire. The motorcyclists is in a very vulnerable position, and you should ensure that in helping them you don't put yourself or others at risk.

column2: How can you help a driver suffering from shock?
column3: Ask who is at fault for causing the accident
column5: Give them a warm, sugary drink
column9: You should call the emergency services to come and help, then reassure the driver, staying with them until the emergency services arrive. The casualty may have injuries that aren't visible, so avoid moving them unless there is further danger.

column2: In which circumstances should a motorcyclist's helmet be removed following a crash?
column4: Immediately, unless they are visibly in shock
column9: You should not remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it is absolutely necessary. Doing so could cause further injury, and they may be suffering from shock. Reassure them with confidence that they will be okay, but don’t let them eat.

column2: There has been an accident involving a motorcyclist. The motorcyclist is unconscious and is lying in the middle of the road. Traffic has stopped and doesn't pose a threat. How should you help?
column9: You should call the emergency services to ensure the motorcyclist gets medical attention as soon as possible. If you cannot phone them yourself, ask someone nearby to do it. You should not move a casualty or remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it is entirely necessary.

column2: Which of these is an appropriate time to use your hazard warning lights?
column3: When driving at night without headlights
column4: If you need to stop and are temporarily obstructing traffic
column5: While travelling slowly to read road signs
column9: Unless being used to warn traffic behind of a hazard or obstruction ahead on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway, hazard warning lights should not be used while moving. They should not be used to warn of illegal or dangerous parking.

column2: What should you do if a warning light comes on while driving?
column4: Continue if there are no visible issues
column5: Have the issue looked into as soon as safely possible
column6: Hope the issue will resolve itself
column9: Warning lights tell you of engine faults and other problems. You should be able to identify any warning light that comes on because they can indicate problems that make your car unsafe to drive. Get a qualified mechanic to check the problem if you're unsure.

column2: If a car is displaying a 'help' pennant, what does it mean?
column3: The driver is more than likely a disabled person
column4: The driver is a rescue patrol officer
column5: The driver is qualified in first aid
column6: The driver is from another country
column9: In the event that a disabled driver can't walk to an emergency phone following a breakdown, the best course of action is for them to stay in their vehicle, turn on their hazard warning lights, and await help. The 'help' pennant indicates when a disabled driver needs assistance.

column2: What must you do if you damage a garden wall with your car, but no one sees?
column3: Report the collision to the police within 24 hours
column4: Tell your insurance company later that day
column5: Tell the owners of the house the next day
column6: Tell someone in the neighbourhood what happened
column9: You should report the collision to the police as soon as possible, and never later than 24 hours afterwards.

column2: You are driving through a tunnel when the traffic ahead slows down and stops. What should you do?
column3: Leave only a small space between you and the vehicle in front
column4: Ignore any signage in the tunnel
column5: If possible, make a U-turn and exit the tunnel
column6: Maintain a safe distance from the vehicle in front of you
column9: Keeping a safe gap between you and the vehicle in front is important, even when moving slowly or stopped in a queue. In a tunnel, leaving space is important for the usual safety reasons, but will also help if you need to manoeuvre around a broken down vehicle.

column2: Following an incident, a small child isn't breathing. You need to administer CPR which include giving rescue breaths. How should you breathe into the child's mouth?
column9: Children and infants have more delicate ribcages than adults, so, after checking their airway is clear, you should use a single hand on their chest (just two fingers for an infant) when giving chest compressions. You should also begin mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, breathing gently until they're able to breathe.

column2: What should you do if you break down in a tunnel?
column3: Stand behind your vehicle and wave traffic past
column4: Stay near your vehicle and warn oncoming traffic
column5: Turn on your hazard warning lights, then call for help
column6: Call the police and stay in your vehicle
column9: You should turn on your hazard warning lights and call for help. In a tunnel, using an emergency telephone usually gets the breakdown sorted sooner. Breakdowns in tunnels can cause severe congestion and danger.

column2: A vehicle has collided with your car What information should you find out if someone is injured and your car is damaged?
column3: What the other driver does for a living
column4: Whether the other driver has a full licence
column5: The name, address, and phone number of the other driver
column6: Where the other driver was going
column9: You should find out the name and address of other involved drivers, as well as the registration numbers of any vehicles involved. The aftermath of a collision can be stressful, but you should try to remain calm. Take pictures of the scene and make note of the positions of vehicles involved; you may need this information for an insurance claim.

column2: Once an area is safe following an incident, how can you look after any casualties?
column5: Keep them in the same position
column6: Help them away from any vehicles
column9: Casualties could have unseen or internal injuries, and moving them could make these worse. It's best not to move them unless staying where they are puts them at further risk.

column2: A collision has taken place in front of you. What is the first thing you should do to help an injured person lying in the middle of a busy road?
column4: Roll them into the recovery position
column6: Check to see if they're in shock
column9: Further collision and vehicle fire are the two most immediate dangers. Warn other traffic by turning on your hazard warning lights (and by placing an advance warning triangle anywhere but on a motorway) and turn off engines to reduce risk of fire. Don't put yourself at risk doing this.

column2: When should you move a casualty who's unconscious but breathing?
column3: When bystanders are there to help
column5: Only if there is further danger
column6: Only when an ambulance has been called
column9: Casualties could have internal injuries or other hidden ailments. Moving them could make these worse, and so casualties should not be moved unless staying put presents a danger. Additionally, only if it's absolutely necessary should a motorcyclist's helmet be removed.

column2: In a long tunnel, what might warn you of an incident or congestion ahead?
column6: Yellow hatch markings on the road
column9: Variable message signs (usually overhead or on the walls) give instructions and warnings about tunnel traffic conditions. Keep watch for the signs changing, and be prepared to stop if they warn of a hazard ahead. Incidents can quickly spiral out of control in congested tunnels, so be wary.

column2: If someone is unconscious following an accident, what is the first thing you should do?
column4: Put something soft under their head
column9: Remember the DR ABC acronym when arriving at crashed where people are injured. Danger (remove risk of further collision or fire), Response (call emergency services), Airway (check their airway is clear), Breathing (check their breathing), Compressions (give chest compressions). Continue providing first aid until the emergency services arrive.

column2: A pedestrian suffers a leg injury following an accident. The leg is bleeding heavily, although it isn't broken and nothing is embedded in the wound. What should you do to help?
column3: Raise the leg to reduce the bleeding
column4: Lay both legs flat on the ground
column5: Get them a drink of water
column9: Raising the leg above heart level will reduce the flow of blood to the limb, and therefore reduce blood loss. Provided there is no debris in the wound, blood loss can be slowed further with a bandage or clean cloth. Tying something around the leg to reduce blood flow is not advised, as it can lead to permanent damage.

column2: How should you use a hand-held device in your car?
column4: Only if you can steer well one-handed
column5: Only on a well lit road
column9: Except in genuine emergencies, it is illegal to use a handheld mobile phone. Doing so will distract you from the road, and increase risk of an accident.

column2: Which of the following is most likely to be a major distraction while driving?
column5: Looking in your rear view mirror
column9: Tuning your radio stations to local radio, planning your route, and taking regular breaks are just a few ways you should prepare for a long journey. Avoid distractions as much as possible. Handheld mobile phone use is illegal except in emergencies, but even hands-free use can be distracting.

column2: How should you use a satellite navigation device (sat nav) without it affecting your driving?
column3: Only when driving in the countryside
column6: Programme the device before beginning your journey
column9: Satellite navigation systems (sat nav) are very useful for unfamiliar journeys, but they can also be distracting. Looking at them could cause you to lose control or miss a hazard ahead. Ensure you're stopped in a safe place before attempting to input information or adjust them.

column2: What should you do before emerging right onto a dual carriageway?
column4: Ensure there is enough room behind you for a second vehicle
column5: Ensure the central reservation is wide enough for your vehicle
column6: Come to a complete stop and select a low gear
column9: You should ensure the central reservation is deep enough to protect your vehicle before emerging right onto a dual carriageway. If it's not, treat the dual carriageway as a single road, and ensure you check both directions before emerging. Not doing this could cause a collision by placing some or all of your vehicle in the path of approaching traffic.

column2: You're approaching a set of traffic lights which have been on green for some time. What should you do?
column9: Always consider when approaching traffic lights on green that they could change to red. Be prepared in case they change and you have to stop, especially if the lights have been green for a while.

column2: While driving on a wet road, you suddenly need stop the car due to an emergency. What should you do to keep safe?
column3: Brake sharply and apply the handbrake
column4: Wave your arm out of the window to warn other drivers
column6: Keep your hands securely on the steering wheel
column9: Paying attention to your surroundings makes it more likely you'll spot hazards early. This means you'll react earlier too, and can keep better control of the vehicle in emergencies. Ensure you keep both hands on the steering wheel to maximise control.

column2: How would using a mobile phone while driving affect you?
column4: It will allow you to drive more carefully
column5: You won't be able to see as well
column9: Even using a hands-free kit can leave you distracted. The person speaking on the other end of the phone can't see the road you're driving and won't know when you need to concentrate, or when a hazard presents itself. The best course of action is to stop in a safe place before making or taking a call.

column2: Before making a U-turn in the road, what should you do?
column3: Glance over your shoulder to check for any oncoming vehicles
column4: Signal by using or arms or indicators
column5: Select a higher gear than you normally would
column6: Select a lower gear than you normally would
column9: Before you perform a U-turn, slow down and have a look to see if the road is clear in both directions. Ensure there is enough space in the road to safely perform the manoeuvre.

column2: What should you do if you get lost in a busy area?
column3: Keep moving and open a map on your phone
column4: Shout to other cars for advice
column5: Stop in the road and ask a pedestrian
column6: Stop somewhere safe and check a map
column9: You should always find a safe place to stop before checking a map or asking for directions.

column2: What should you do before moving out on to the road from a parked position?
column4: Pull out and then look around
column6: Check your rear view and side mirrors to see what's around
column9: You should check your exterior and interior mirrors to make sure the road is clear before moving off. Check your blind spots too, and be prepared to use arm signals if you feel other drivers might not understand your intentions.

column2: You're driving on a narrow country road and see a cyclist ahead. How should you pass?
column3: Pass as close to them as possible
column4: Accelerate past as quickly as possible
column5: Only pass if it is safe, leaving plenty of room
column6: Sound your horn as you pass them
column9: Cyclists often need to weave around potholes, and sometimes need to adjust their course to correct their balance. Allow them plenty of room when you overtake, and pay close attention to the road ahead, looking for farm entrances or driveways where vehicles might pull out.

column2: Why do these yellow lines sometimes appear on the road?
column3: To make you aware of how fast you're going
column4: To help you keep the correct distance from the vehicle in front of you
column5: To guide you to the correct lane
column6: To inform you of the distance to the next exit
column9: These lines are a form of traffic calming measure. They are often present just before roundabouts and dangerous junctions. They prompt you to reduce your speed. You should look ahead and do this in good time.

column2: In which of the following situations are you permitted to use a mobile phone in your car?
column9: Except in genuine emergencies, it is illegal to use a handheld mobile phone. Hands-free kits make phone use possible, but are still distracting. The safest approach is to stop in a safe place before making or receiving a call. Your hands will also be free to take notes if needed.

column2: It starts to get dark while you're driving. Why should you switch on your lights?
column3: To make your dials light up
column4: To see and be seen more easily
column5: Because the street lights are on
column6: Because everyone else is doing it
column9: When visibility is poor during the day, it may be necessary to turn on your headlights and tail lights to help other drivers spot you. This is especially true in early morning or in late afternoon, when the operation of streetlamps might not be timed optimally to help drivers see clearly.

column2: You're driving on the motorway and start to feel sleepy. What should you do?
column3: Stop for a rest on the hard shoulder
column4: Drink an energy drink to get you through
column5: Leave at the first opportunity and find a safe place to stop
column9: Fresh air can help keep you alert when you begin to feel tired, but your first priority should always be using the next service area or motorway exit to find a safe place to rest.

column2: How should you approach this bridge?
column9: Slow down and exercise caution. The bridge is narrow, so passing an oncoming vehicle may not be possible. There is also no footpath, so keep an eye out for pedestrians in the road.

column2: What should you do if you can't get a clear view behind you while reversing?
column4: Open the door to see behind you
column5: Lean out of the window and look behind
column6: Look only in the nearside mirror
column9: Ensure you can see all around your vehicle before attempting to turn your car around. Get someone to guide you if you're unable to get a good look around.

column2: What should you do if your mobile phone starts ringing while you're driving?
column3: Pull up at the nearest kerb
column6: Check to see who's calling you
column9: Using a mobile phone or a similar device while driving or riding is against the law, except in the case of an emergency. For your safety, you should switch off your mobile phone before leaving and set it to voice mail. If your phone rings because you forgot to turn it off, ignore it. When you've come to a safe stop, you can check your phone and, if necessary, return the call.

column3: An area that isn't covered by your headlights
column4: The area covered by your right-hand mirror
column5: An area not visible in your mirrors
column6: The space right behind the driver's seat
column9: Even modern vehicles have blind spots, areas of the vehicle's surroundings not visible through its mirrors. It's therefore essential that you look around to check these areas are clear when necessary.

column2: What should you do before stopping your car?
column9: Before pulling over or coming to a stop, always check your mirrors to see who is behind you. Don't forget to use your indicators if pulling off or stopping by the road.

column2: The windscreen pillar is hindering your view at a junction. Which of the following vehicles should you particularly keep an eye out for?
column9: Approaching motorcyclists, pedestrians, and cyclists can be entirely obscured by windscreen pillars. Take extra time to look for these road users. Don't assume a quick glance is enough.

column2: You're driving behind an LGV (Large Goods Vehicle). Why should you keep well back?
column4: The LGV driver will see you in their mirrors
column5: So you can take corners quicker
column6: To leave space for other cars
column9: LGV and van drivers don't have rear view mirrors. Remember to stay well back from them, because if you can't see their side mirrors, they can't see you. This will also help you see more of the road.

column2: What could happen if you hang objects from your rear-view mirror?
column4: You could be distracted or have your view blocked
column9: Anything dangling from your rear view mirror or stuck to your windscreen could distract you from driving properly. Make sure you can see through your windscreen clearly.

column2: Why should you use your mirrors after you've spotted a hazard up ahead?
column3: To see what's ahead of you
column4: To check to see if you can do an emergency stop
column5: To check whether you can accelerate
column6: To assess the situation around you and react accordingly
column9: You should be checking your mirrors regularly, ensuring you always know what's ahead, beside, and behind you. Doing this will help you anticipate what might happen next, helping avoid and prevent hazards. It's especially important to check your mirrors when you spot a hazard.

column2: In which of the following situations would windscreen pillars hinder your view of the road?
column9: Smaller vehicles and road users - pedestrians, motorcyclists, and cyclists - can be hidden by your windscreen pillars. Be sure to move your head to look past them to check the road at bends and junctions.

column2: In which of the following situations should you NOT overtake?
column4: When approaching a dip in the road
column9: Prior to overtaking, consider if it’s really needed. If you can’t see far enough, keep back and wait for a better place to pull out.

column2: You intend to turn right at a junction but your view is blocked by parked vehicles. What should you do?
column3: Reverse away from the junction and find another route
column4: Move forward quickly to get a clear view
column5: Get out and have a look at what's approaching
column6: Stop at the junction, then edge forward until you have a clear view
column9: Buildings, parked cars, and trees often restrict visibility at junctions. To ensure emerging is safe, edge forward slowly to look past obstructions. Ensure you don't cause other drivers to change speed when you pull out.
